comments: Johnathan

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: I think this course needs more social scientist input (which Dave acknowledges and tried to redress). It might be good to have some more general readings to unify the class discussion. However, the workshop aspect of the course was really useful, and Dave's insights into the PhD process were extremely helpful. He always knows what to say, and he reads people very well. Both he and Jonathon helped me a lot on my final project, and I enjoyed following the work of my classmates too.

Q10: Course relevanceThe pace of the course was slow owing to the self-direction associated with student projects. Paired guest lectures and conversations with the speaker were very interesting on nearly all topics, and offered perspective for those considering academic, research or policy focused careers. Being provided a safe and engaged space to float research ideas, formulate methods or draft grant/fellowship applications was invaluable. Adding official readings to the course would detract from this. The current focus is perfect.
see above -- I loved the workshop structure
Gaining new perspectives or new angles on my research via the projects/approaches of others. The class represents varied interests - which I see as a strength in this context.

I enjoyed being able to talk to each of the guest speakers and learn about how they ended up where they are today. Even though speakers were not necessarily within my exact field, I still found it very helpful to learn about the paths they chose and the decisions that were made along the way.
open discussionsstudent feedbackvaried topics
Getting to know my DGS; getting to know other students in the program and their background and research interests; having a chance to meet speakers and talk with them in a small group setting.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: I think we need more of a common language amongst the doctoral students -- more general readings and perhaps more divisive speakers would help.

Possibly one or two required readings on scientific method etc., but not more. More speakers with an explicit social science focus - although the instructor made mention of the difficulty in confirming speakers from social science disciplines.

The only thing that really disappointed me was the behavior of the class as a whole. It seemed painfully obvious when people weren't engaged and the fact that there were so many open computers seemed completely disrespectful to the guest speakers. I'm not sure whether there is anything that can be done structurally to mend this, but it was frustrating nonetheless.
ideally, class discussion should be facilitated by an instructor in the lull and transition periods, while students should have primary voice during all other times.extremely competitive

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: Dave and Jonathon both went out of their way to make this first semester an enjoyable and stimulating experience.
Both the instructor and the TA were accessible and very helpful when needed.
Both instructor and TA made themselves very available to consultation.
Both the TA and the instructor were accessible and responsive to students outside of class. They were both thoroughly helpful.

The instructor (Skelly) was marvelously accessible - I deeply appreciate how much time he gave to us. I didn't reach out much to the TA, but do appreciate that he stayed involved in the class even after becoming a father during the semester.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: Program requirement

I thought that this was a good introduction to the doctoral program. It was interesting to learn more about the structure of the program and the rough path that all of us will be taking in the next few years.

Exposure to a variety of topics in Environmental Studies was critical to my overall education this semester. I appreciated being introduced to areas in which I had no background or knowledge. I feel that this exposure enhanced my ability 1) to recognize the full spectrum of environmental issues being addressed,2) to appreciate the breadth and depth of scientific research underway, and 3) to weave common themes together from this array of research that deepen my understanding of my own focus area. This exposure is a superb balancing mechanism to prevent doctoral students from becoming myopic. It forces us to learn and think about topics beyond our scope, ultimately making us better equipped to generate insights about our own topic.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Required
Program requirement
This was a requirement for the doctoral program.
It is required.
required

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: I had no expectations. That said, this course helped me make the shift from professional to academic.
I had low expectations - and it turned out better than envisioned.
I guess I didn't know what to expect, but it certainly was useful and interesting.
Yes.

comments: yes
Yes.

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Don't be afraid to ask the illustrious speakers dumb questions.
Use the class and instructor/ta's to your advantage. This is the perfect opportunity to prepare a grant/fellowship application due to the attention you will receive and the feedback you will get.
You will get out of this course what you put into it. Put something into it.
